channel.title: Which foreign country do you want to visit?
channel.description:
Japan.
When i was a child Japan always fascinated me, the food, the lights, the people and the products.
[img]http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Minato_Mirai_In_Blue.jpg/800px-Minato_Mirai_In_Blue.jpg[/img]
[img]http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Shibuya_night.jpg/800px-Shibuya_night.jpg[/img]
[img]http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Himeji_Castle_The_Keep_Towers.jpg/800px-Himeji_Castle_The_Keep_Towers.jpg[/img]
[img]http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kamidaigo05_1024.jpg/800px-Kamidaigo05_1024.jpg[/img]

item.title: Which foreign country do you want to visit?
item.dc:creator: @ChaosPkers ChaosPkers
item.description:
@ChaosPkers wrote:

[quote="`Aaron, post:20, topic:369137"][quote author=ChaosPkers link=topic=465263.msg3402535#msg3402535 date=1290059017]

Casey, why would you want to go to Pripyat? it’s been abandoned since 1986.

Iirc the radiation levels are livable now, so they have started to rebuild and what not.

Not everywhere, the zone of alienation is the only place even remotely close to being safe to enter.
[/quote]k i looked up the place u guys r talking about… world war 2 stuff, why does it have radiation?

Wrong, 1986 is not WW2.

The disaster occurred on 26 April 1986, at reactor number four at the Chernobyl plant, near the town of Pripyat, during an unauthorized systems test. A sudden power output surge took place, and when an attempt was made at an emergency shutdown, a more extreme spike in power output occurred which led to the rupture of a reactor vessel as well as a series of explosions. This event exposed the graphite moderator components of the reactor to air and they ignited; the resulting fire sent a plume of radioactive fallout into the atmosphere and over an extensive area, including Pripyat. The plume drifted over large parts of the western Soviet Union, and much of Europe. As of December 2000, 350,400 people had been evacuated and resettled from the most severely contaminated areas of Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine.

Pripyat is just a city that was affected.[/quote]oh. well what i read it was fought over between the soviets and nazis.

Read full topic
item.source: Which foreign country do you want to visit?

item.title: Which foreign country do you want to visit?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

[quote=“casey., post:21, topic:369137”]Pripyat was the city that most of the plant workers lived at, when the accident occurred, they left.

I’m sure most of you played the greatest game on earth, COD4. Just as the game says, “50,000 people used to live hear, now it’s a ghost-town.”
How awesome is that?
The city combined with Ukrainian climate, the history, how everything is exactly the same for almost 25 years…it’s really interesting.

Also, I don’t think it’s livable fully yet, only for a few hours(people do live there, but obviously suffer from the effects of radiation)[/quote]

568px-Chernobyl_radiation_map_1996.svg.png568×600

The city itself is not livable yet, but the “Unnamed” areas around it are now livable (iirc, most of that was not at the time). Also “The Zone of Alienation is considered relatively safe to visit, and several Ukrainian companies offer guided tours around the area. The radiation levels have dropped considerably, compared to the fatal levels of April 1986 due to the decay of the short-lived isotopes released during the accident. In most places within the city, the level of radiation does not exceed equivalent dose of 1 μSv (one microsievert) per hour.”

Read full topic
item.source: Which foreign country do you want to visit?

But if I didn’t get to go to Sweden I would have to say the UK, Because I would get to go find CJ<3

item.title: Which foreign country do you want to visit?
item.dc:creator: @gothic_queen casey.
item.description:
@gothic_queen wrote:

Pripyat was the city that most of the plant workers lived at, when the accident occurred, they left.

I’m sure most of you played the greatest game on earth, COD4. Just as the game says, “50,000 people used to live hear, now it’s a ghost-town.”
How awesome is that?
The city combined with Ukrainian climate, the history, how everything is exactly the same for almost 25 years…it’s really interesting.

Also, I don’t think it’s livable fully yet, only for a few hours(people do live there, but obviously suffer from the effects of radiation)

Read full topic

item.title: Which foreign country do you want to visit?
item.dc:creator: @n33bz0rpl0x `Aaron
item.description:
@n33bz0rpl0x wrote:

[quote=“ChaosPkers, post:19, topic:369137”][quote author=`Aaron link=topic=465263.msg3402529#msg3402529 date=1290057766]

Casey, why would you want to go to Pripyat? it’s been abandoned since 1986.

Iirc the radiation levels are livable now, so they have started to rebuild and what not.

Not everywhere, the zone of alienation is the only place even remotely close to being safe to enter.
[/quote]k i looked up the place u guys r talking about… world war 2 stuff, why does it have radiation?[/quote]

Wrong, 1986 is not WW2.

The disaster occurred on 26 April 1986, at reactor number four at the Chernobyl plant, near the town of Pripyat, during an unauthorized systems test. A sudden power output surge took place, and when an attempt was made at an emergency shutdown, a more extreme spike in power output occurred which led to the rupture of a reactor vessel as well as a series of explosions. This event exposed the graphite moderator components of the reactor to air and they ignited; the resulting fire sent a plume of radioactive fallout into the atmosphere and over an extensive area, including Pripyat. The plume drifted over large parts of the western Soviet Union, and much of Europe. As of December 2000, 350,400 people had been evacuated and resettled from the most severely contaminated areas of Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine.

Pripyat is just a city that was affected.
